moredefinition.definition: To regard with horror or detestation; to shrink back with shuddering from; to feel excessive repugnance toward; to detest to extremity; to loathe.
To turn aside or avoid; to keep away from; to reject.
(obsolete, impersonal) To fill with horror or disgust.
(canon law, obsolete) To protest against; to reject solemnly.
(obsolete) To shrink back with horror, disgust, or dislike; to be contrary or averse; construed with from.
(obsolete) Differ entirely from.
To endure without yielding; to withstand; await defiantly; to encounter; to persevere.
examples: The old oak tree abides the wind endlessly.

moredefinition.definition: To bear patiently; to tolerate; to put up with; stand.
To pay for; to stand the consequences of; to answer for; to suffer for; to atone for.
(obsolete) To wait in expectation.
(obsolete) To pause; to delay.
(archaic) To stay; to continue in a place; to remain stable or fixed in some state or condition; to be left.
(archaic) To have one's abode; to dwell; to reside; to sojourn.
(archaic) To endure; to remain; to last.
examples: 1998, "The Big Lebowski" — The Dude abides.

moredefinition.definition: (archaic) To stand ready for; to await for someone; watch for.
(obsolete) To endure or undergo a hard trial or a task; to stand up under.
(archaic) To await submissively; accept without question; submit to.
(chiefly dialectal) To bear; to endure; to tolerate.
(archaic or dialectal) To dwell or reside in a location; to abide.
(archaic or dialectal) To wait; to be in expectation; to stay; to remain.
(archaic) To wait for; to await.
(reflexive) To flee, often secretly; to steal away, particularly to avoid arrest or prosecution.
examples: The thieves absconded with our property.
1911, Ambrose Bierce, "The Devil's Dictionary" — Spring beckons! All things to the call respond; The trees are leaving and cashiers abscond.

moredefinition.definition: To withdraw from.
examples: 2006, Richard Rojcewicz, "The Gods And Technology: A Reading Of Heidegger" — Modern technology accompanies the absconding of the original attitude.

2009, Sonia Brill, "Relationships Without Anger" — You cannot abscond from the responsibility both you and your partner owe to this event, and that includes dealing with anger issues and any other emotional issues that come with it.

moredefinition.definition: To evade, to hide or flee from.
examples: The captain absconded his responsibility.

2006, Aldo E. Chircop, Olof Lindén, "Places of Refuge for Ships" — If the distress situation is solved successfully, the anonymous shipowner will reap the commercial benefit, if the situation ends in disaster, the shipowner will hide behind an anonymous post box in a foreign country and will abscond responsibility.
2008, Somar, "The Mystical Harvest" — The driver snatched a packet of cigarettes out of the glove compartment and absconded the driver's seat without a word

2007, Vendela Vida, "Girls on the Verge: Debutante Dips, Drive-bys, and Other Initiations" — Those who evidently did not get invited back to their top choices have already absconded the scene, tripping in their high heels as they ran.
2011, James Morton, Susanna Lobez, "Gangland Melbourne" — In 1939 she absconded her bail in Melbourne and went to New Zealand, where she also absconded on a charge of stealing diamonds.

moredefinition.definition: (obsolete) To conceal; to take away.
(archaic, reflexive) To hide, to be in hiding or concealment.
(poetic) An acclamation; a shout of applause.
(obsolete) A claim.
To shout approval; to express great approval.
examples: 1911, Saki, The Chronicles of Clovis - The design, when finally developed, was a slight disappointment to Monsieur Deplis, who had suspected Icarus of being a fortress taken by Wallenstein in the Thirty Years' War, but he was more than satisfied with the execution of the work, which was acclaimed by all who had the privilege of seeing it as Pincini's masterpiece.

moredefinition.definition: To declare by acclamations.
(Canada, politics) To elect to an office by having no opposition.
(archaic) To shout; to call out.
(rare) To salute or praise with great approval; to compliment; to applaud; to welcome enthusiastically.
(obsolete) To claim.
A shout of approbation, favor, or assent; eager expression of approval; loud applause.
The process of electing a person to a post in the absence of other nominees.
examples: With no one running against her, she won by acclamation.

moredefinition.definition: (art) A representation, in sculpture or on medals, of people expressing joy.
(politics) An oral vote taken without formal ballot and with much fanfare; typically an overwhelmingly affirmative vote.
An expression of approval; praise.
(historical) A salutation marking the conferring of knighthood, consisting of an embrace or a kiss, and a slight blow on the shoulders with the flat of a sword.
A special acknowledgment; an award.
examples: 2016, Phil McNulty, "BBC" — Rooney led Manchester United up the Wembley steps to collect the FA Cup and add a missing medal to his collection - a richly deserved accolade.

moredefinition.definition: (music) A brace used to join two or more staves.
An embrace of greeting or salutation.

(US, military) Written Presidential certificate recognizing service by personnel who died or were wounded in action between 1917 and 1918, or who died in service between 1941 and 1947, or died of wounds received in Korea between June 27, 1950 and July 27, 1954. Service of civilians who died overseas or as a result of injury or disease contracted while serving in a civilian capacity with the United States Armed Forces during the dates and/or in areas prescribed is in like manner recognized.

(architecture) An ornament composed of two ogee curves meeting in the middle, each concave toward its outer extremity and convex toward the point at which it meets the other. Such accolades are either plain or adorned with rich moldings, and are a frequent motive of decoration on the lintels of doors and windows of the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries, especially in secular architecture.
Synonym of curly bracket
To embrace or kiss in salutation.
(historical) To confer a knighthood on.
To confer praise or awards on.
examples: an accoladed novel

moredefinition.definition: Quickness of perception or discernment; penetration of mind; the faculty of nice discrimination.
examples: 1905, Arthur Conan Doyle, "The Return of Sherlock Holmes" — No, no, my dear Watson! With all respect for your natural acumen, I do not think that you are quite a match for the worthy doctor.
1991, "The Silence of the Lambs", Ted Tally — Why do you think he removes their skins, Agent Starling? Enthrall me with your acumen.

moredefinition.definition: (botany) A sharp, tapering point extending from a plant.
examples: 1956, S.M. Bukasov, "Translation of THEORETICAL BASES OF PLAN BREEDING" — 11. S. boyacense. Resembles S. Rybinii from which it is distinguished by the greater dissection of the leaves, the longer calyx acumens, smaller anthers and coloured corolla.

1978, "The Potato Crop: The scientific basis for improvement" — Herbs with long creeping stolons; leaves with coarse white hairs, or glabrous. The arched corolla lobes and large acumens give the corolla a circular appearance with acumens standing out sharply from it. Corolla occasionally, however, substellate.

1990, "Cryptogamic Botany, Volume 2" — In our opinion, specimens of I. pilifera represent a robust expression of I. sinensis with many stem and branch leaves becoming strongly concave and broadly ovate to obovate in outline, thereby intensifying the abrupt contraction of the pilaferous acumens. It is best accepted as a variety of N. comes. The length of leaf acumens is another variable character expressed by Barbella amoena. Thus, it is also better combined with the var. pilifera as a synonym.

moredefinition.definition: (anatomy) A bony, often sharp, protuberance, especially that of the ischium.
examples: 1981, Horton Holcombe Hobbs, "The Crayfishes of Georgia: Issue 318 of Smithsonian contributions to zoology, Smithsonian Institution" — DIAGNOSIS—Rostrum usually with marginal spines, tubercles, or angles at base of acumen, and rarely with low medina carina.

1993, Biological Society of Washington, Smithsonian Institution, "Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington, Volume 106" — Variations.—Most specimens examined have concave rostral margins that taper to the acumen and the rostral length is greater than the rostral width.

moredefinition.definition: To warn or notify of a fault; to reprove gently or kindly, but seriously; to exhort.
examples: 2017, Brandon Nowalk, "The Onion AV Club" — Plucky old Walder Frey gathers his family for a feast and toasts to their massacre of the Stark family. He compliments their bravery in stabbing a pregnant woman and her fetus to death. As every last Frey man swigs their special wine, Walder hypes the cunning it took to invite guests into your home and ambush them. But then things take a turn, the men starting to keel over as Walder seems to admonish them for leaving certain threads hanging. At last the room is empty but for Arya Stark, holding Walder Frey’s face, and a couple girls she leaves alive to spread the legend. “Winter came for House Frey.”

moredefinition.definition: To counsel against wrong practices; to caution or advise; to warn against danger or an offense; - followed by of, against, or a subordinate clause.
To instruct or direct; to inform; to notify.
To make more beautiful and attractive; to decorate.
examples: a man adorned with noble statuary and columns
a character adorned with every Christian grace
a gallery of paintings was adorned with the works of some of the great masters
1980, "Walls and Ceilings" — Durable, water-resistant and easy to clean, tiles have adorned Persian mosques, Moorish palaces and the parlors of Dutch burgers.

moredefinition.definition: (obsolete) adornment
(obsolete) adorned; ornate
The action of adulterating, being mixed with extraneous material, illicit substitution of one substance for another.
To corrupt.
To spoil by adding impurities.
examples: to adulterate food, drink, drugs, coins, etc.
Spectator: The present war has [...] adulterated our tongue with strange words.

moredefinition.definition: To commit adultery.
To defile by adultery.
Tending to commit adultery.
Corrupted; impure; adulterated.
To foreshadow vaguely.
To give a vague outline.
examples: 1996, John M. Cooper, "Introduction" in Plato: Complete Works, Hackett, p. xxii: Accordingly, even though readers always and understandably speak of the theories adumbrated by Socrates here as "Plato's theories", one ought not to speak of them so without some compunction--the writing itself, and also Plato the author, present these always in a spirit of open-ended exploration, and sometimes there are contextual clues indicating that Socrates exaggerates or goes what the argument truly justifies, and so on.

moredefinition.definition: To obscure or overshadow.
Receiving others kindly and conversing with them in a free and friendly manner; friendly, courteous, sociable.
examples: 1912: James Burrill Angell, The Reminiscences Of James Burrill Angell, chapter ix "Mission To The Ottoman Empire" - Furthermore, I may say, that the Sultan was always most affable to me in my interviews with him, even when I had to discuss some missionary questions. In fact, I never saw any traces of the difficulties which Mr. Terrell reported.

moredefinition.definition: Mild; benign.
examples: 1998: Alexia Maria Kosmider, Tricky Tribal Discourse, page 84 - During more affable weather, the four friends congregate outside, sometimes leaning their hickory chairs against a "catapa" tree...

moredefinition.definition: To make (an offence) worse or more severe; to increase in offensiveness or heinousness.
(now chiefly colloquial) To exasperate; to provoke or irritate.
examples: 1977, Alistair Horne, A Savage War of Peace, New York Review Books 2006, p. 85: Ben Bella was aggravated by having to express himself in French because the Egyptians were unable to understand his Arabic.

moredefinition.definition: (by extension) To make worse; to exacerbate.
(now rare) To give extra weight or intensity to; to exaggerate, to magnify.
examples: He aggravated the story.

moredefinition.definition: (obsolete) To pile or heap (something heavy or onerous) on or upon someone.
Loyalty to some cause, nation or ruler.
To make less severe, as a pain or difficulty.
examples: Alcohol is often a cheap tool to alleviate the stress of a hard day.

moredefinition.definition: To merge, to combine, to blend, to join.
examples: to amalgamate two races
to amalgamate one race with another

moredefinition.definition: To make an alloy of a metal and mercury.
(mathematics) To combine (free groups) by identifying respective isomorphic subgroups.
Coalesced; united; combined.
Open to multiple interpretations.
examples: The politician was criticized for his ambiguous statements and lack of precision.

moredefinition.definition: Vague and unclear.
examples: He gave an ambiguous answer.

moredefinition.definition: (obsolete, of persons) Hesitant; uncertain; not taking sides.
To make better, or improve, something perceived to be in a negative condition.
examples: They offered some compromises in an effort to ameliorate the situation.

moredefinition.definition: To become better; improve.
To make better; to improve; to solve a problem.
examples: They offered some compromises in an effort to meliorate the disagreement.

moredefinition.definition: To become better.
Extreme pain, either of body or mind; excruciating distress.
To suffer pain.
examples: 1900, Kl. Knigge, Iceland Folk Song, traditional, Harmony: H. Ruland - We’re leaving these shores for our time has come, the days of our youth must now end. The hearts bitter anguish, it burns for the home that we’ll never see again.

moredefinition.definition: To cause to suffer pain.
A remedy to counteract the effects of poison (often followed by "against," "for," or "to").
examples: She reached the hospital in time to receive the antidote for the snake venom.
2014, Olivia Judson, "The New York Times" — The druids [...] believed that mistletoe could make barren animals fecund, and that it was an antidote to all poisons.

moredefinition.definition: (figuratively) Something that counteracts or prevents something harmful.
examples: We need an antidote for this misinformation.

moredefinition.definition: To counteract as an antidote.
examples: 2007, Suzanne C. Lawton, Judyth Reichenberg-Ullman, Asperger syndrome: natural steps toward a better life (page 143) - For his part, the patient must avoid some commonplace substances in order to avoid antidoting or stopping the action of the homeopathic remedy [...]

moredefinition.definition: To make quiet; to calm; to reduce to a state of peace; to dispel (anger or hatred).
examples: to appease the tumult of the ocean

moredefinition.definition: To come to terms with; to adapt to the demands of.
examples: They appeased the angry gods with burnt offerings.

moredefinition.definition: The state of being arrogant; a type of extreme or foolish pride in which someone feels much superior to another
Having excessive pride in oneself, often with contempt or disrespect for others.
examples: 1987, Sam Donaldson, "Hold On, Mr President!" — Call me a braggart, call me arrogant. People at ABC (and elsewhere) have called me worse. But when you need the job done on deadline, you’ll call me.

moredefinition.definition: To move upward, to fly, to soar.
examples: He ascended to heaven upon a cloud.

moredefinition.definition: To slope in an upward direction.
To go up.
examples: You ascend the stairs and take a right.

moredefinition.definition: To succeed.
examples: She ascended the throne when her mother abdicated.

moredefinition.definition: (figuratively) To rise; to become higher, more noble, etc.
To trace, search or go backwards temporally (e.g., through records, genealogies, routes, etc.).
examples: Our inquiries ascend to the remotest antiquity.

moredefinition.definition: (music) To become higher in pitch.
Showing willingness to take bold risks; recklessly daring.
examples: 2012, Scott Tobias, AV Club The Hunger Games[http://www.avclub.com/articles/the-hunger-games,71293/] - That such a safe adaptation could come of The Hunger Games speaks more to the trilogy’s commercial ascent than the book’s actual content, which is audacious and savvy in its dark calculations.

2014, "The New York Times" — The audacious hijacking in Paris of a van carrying the baggage of a Saudi prince to his private jet is obviously an embarrassment to the French capital, whose ultra-high-end boutiques have suffered a spate of heists in recent months.

moredefinition.definition: Impudent.
Someone who constantly brags or boasts.
examples: 1922, Emily Post, "Etiquette in Society, in Business, in Politics, and at Home" — A very good resolve to make and keep, if you would also keep any friends you make, is never to speak of anyone without, in imagination, having them overhear what you say. One often hears the exclamation “I would say it to her face!” At least be very sure that this is true, and not a braggart’s phrase and then—nine times out of ten think better of it and refrain.

moredefinition.definition: Characterized by boasting; boastful.
To boast; to talk with excessive pride about what one has, is able to do, or has done; often as an attempt to popularize oneself.
examples: to brag of one's exploits, courage, or money

moredefinition.definition: To boast of.
A boast or boasting; bragging; ostentatious pretence or self-glorification.
The thing which is boasted of.
examples: 2015, Matt Preston, "The Simple Secrets to Cooking Everything Better" — You could just use ordinary shop-bought kecap manis to marinade the meat, but making your own is easy, has a far more elegant fragrance and is, above all, such a great brag! Flavouring kecap manis is an intensely personal thing, so try this version now and next time cook the sauce down with crushed, split lemongrass and a shredded lime leaf.

moredefinition.definition: (by ellipsis) The card game three card brag.
Excellent; first-rate.
(archaic) Brisk; full of spirits; boasting; pretentious; conceited.
examples: a woundy, brag young fellow

moredefinition.definition: (obsolete) proudly; boastfully
Inflexible, liable to break or snap easily under stress or pressure.
examples: Cast iron is much more brittle than forged iron.
A diamond is hard but brittle.

1951, Geoffrey Chaucer, "The Canterbury Tales: Translated into Modern English" — 'Do you suppose our convent, and I too, / Are insufficient, then, to pray for you? / Thomas, that joke's not good. Your faith is brittle.

moredefinition.definition: Not physically tough or tenacious; apt to break or crumble when bending.
examples: Shortbread is my favorite cold pastry, yet being so brittle it crumbles easily, and a lot goes to waste.

moredefinition.definition: Emotionally fragile, easily offended.
examples: What a brittle personality! A little misunderstanding and he's an emotional wreck.

moredefinition.definition: (archaeology) Said of rocks and minerals with a conchoidal fracture; capable of being knapped or flaked.
(informal, proscribed) Diabetes that is characterized by dramatic swings in blood sugar level.
A confection of caramelized sugar and nuts.
examples: As a child, my favorite candy was peanut brittle.

moredefinition.definition: Anything resembling this confection, such as flapjack, a cereal bar, etc.
(chemistry) A substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction without being consumed in the process.
examples: 1988, Lubert Stryer Biochemistry, 3rd edition, page 177 - Enzymes, the catalysts of biological systems, are remarkable molecular devices that determine the pattern of chemical transformations.

moredefinition.definition: Someone or something that encourages progress or change.
examples: Economic development and integration are working as a catalyst for peace.

1978, Ernest George Schwiebert, "Trout" — It was a morning baptized by my first cup of coffee, freshly brewed over a gravel-bar fire, while they celebrated with the stronger catalyst of sour-mash whiskey in their fishing-vest cups.
2004, Michael B. Oren, "Six Days of War: June 1967 and the making of the modern Middle East" — Israel's fear for the reactor—rather than Egypt's of it—was the greater catalyst for war.

2006, The Freedom Writers, with Erin Gruwell, The Freedom Writers Diary: How a Teacher and 150 Teens Used Writing to Change Themselves and the World Around Them, Diary 74 - Rosa Parks was a true catalyst for change and she was only one person. Hearing about Rosa Parks and her protest showed me that there is hope for me and all the students in Ms. G's classes to truly be catalysts for change.

2014, Rupert Christiansen, "The Daily Telegraph (Review)" — He [countertenor Anthony Roth Constanzo] also enjoys being the catalyst whereby opera fertilises other art forms: recently, he's collaborated with Japanese kabuki actors, and a project with dancers from New York City Ballet is in the offing.

moredefinition.definition: (literature) An inciting incident that sets the successive conflict into motion.
(automotive) A catalytic converter.
(chemistry) Of or relating to a catalyst; having properties facilitating chemical reaction or change.

A cutting tool consisting of a slim, oblong block of metal with a sharp wedge or bevel formed on one end. It may be provided with a handle at the other end. It is used to remove parts of stone, wood or metal by placing the sharp edge against the material to be cut and pushing or pounding the other end with a hammer or mallet.
Gravel.
(usually plural) Coarse flour; bran; the coarser part of bran or flour.
To use a chisel.
To work something with a chisel.
examples: She chiselled a sculpture out of the block of wood.

moredefinition.definition: (informal) To cheat, to get something by cheating.
The body or class of people who frequent an establishment or purchase a service, especially when considered as forming a more-or-less homogeneous group of clients in terms of values or habits.
examples: Helen's clientele encompasses a broad range of different ages, races and social statuses.
1997: Chris Horrocks, Introducing Foucault, page 34 (Totem Books, Icon Books; ) - The bars’ clientèle called Foucault “Herr Doktor”.
1998, Patricia Bates, "Billboard" — Due to its mixed clientele over the years, the Record Rack has a varied product array.

moredefinition.definition: A customer, a buyer or receiver of goods or services.
One who receives help or services from a professional such as a lawyer or accountant.
(computing) The role of a computer application or system that requests and/or consumes the services provided by another having the role of server.

(law) A person who employs or retains an attorney to represent him or her in any legal matter, or one who merely divulges confidential matters to an attorney while pursuing professional assistance without subsequently retaining the attorney.
(chemistry) The act or process of burning.
A process where two chemicals are combined to produce heat.
A process wherein a fuel is combined with oxygen, usually at high temperature, releasing heat.
(figuratively) Violent agitation, tumult.
To burn; to catch fire.
examples: 2014, Adelais Selwyn, "Eadric" — Brom swore after that he spoke only the truth, the truth that as he sat by my side praying for my soul, my body had combusted into flame, the fire rapidly engulfing my entire being.

moredefinition.definition: (figuratively) To erupt with enthusiasm or boisterousness.
examples: 2012, Oliver Burkeman, "The Antidote, Happiness for People who Can't Stand Positive Thinking" — The audience combusts.

moredefinition.definition: (astrology) In close conjunction with the sun (so that its astrological influence is "burnt up"), sometimes specified to be within 8 degrees 30'.
(obsolete) Burnt.
(obsolete) That which undergoes burning.
To honour the memory of someone or something with a ceremony or object.
examples: On November 11th we commemorate the fallen with a march.

2009, Naava Piatka, No Goodbyes: A Father-Daughter Memoir of Love, War and Resurrection, page 98: On the anniversary of Korczak's murder, Israel commemorated him with a special postal issue. As a stamp collector and philatelic columnist, it pleased me greatly when other countries followed Israel's example in honoring him.

moredefinition.definition: To serve as a memorial to someone or something.
examples: The cenotaph commemorates the fallen.

moredefinition.definition: Compliant.
Willing to do what pleases others; obliging.
(archaic) Polite; showing respect.
To hide something from view or from public knowledge, to try to keep something secret.
examples: He tried to conceal the truth about his health.

moredefinition.definition: To join together; to unite; to combine.
examples: They are representatives that will loosely conjoin a nation.

moredefinition.definition: To marry.
examples: I will conjoin you in holy matrimony.

moredefinition.definition: (grammar) To join as coordinate elements, often with a coordinating conjunction, such as coordinate clauses.
(mathematics) To combine two sets, conditions, or expressions by a logical AND; to intersect.
To unite, to join, to league.
To signify beyond its literal or principal meaning.
examples: Racism often connotes an underlying fear or ignorance.

moredefinition.definition: To possess an inseparable related condition; to imply as a logical consequence.
examples: Poverty connotes hunger.

moredefinition.definition: To express without overt reference; to imply.
To require as a logical predicate to consequence.
Having hidden meaning.
Mystified or of an obscure nature.
Involving use of a code or cipher.
Of a crossword, or a clue in such a crossword, using, in addition to definitions, wordplay such as anagrams, homophones and hidden words to indicate solutions.
(zoology) Well camouflaged; having good camouflage.
examples: Lonomia caterpillars are extremely cryptic.

moredefinition.definition: (zoology) Serving as camouflage.
examples: cryptic colouring

1911, "The Encyclopædia Britannica" — Episematic characters are far less common than aposematic, and these than cryptic; although, as regards the latter comparison, the opposite impression is generally produced from the fact that concealment is so successfully attained.

moredefinition.definition: (biology, not comparable) Apparently identical, but actually genetically distinct.
examples: cryptic species

moredefinition.definition: (zoology) Living in a cavity or small cave.
examples: 1999, Rachel Wood, Reef Evolution, p. 95: Much of the Permian Capitan reef was strongly differentiated into open surface and cryptic communities.

moredefinition.definition: (informal) A cryptic crossword.
examples: 1996, Mary McCarthy, "Remember Me" — He settled down to the cryptic in the Independent. He loved his crossword. It kept him mentally active, just as gossip did his wife.
2009, Bill Taylor, Building a crossword (in Toronto Star, 1 February 2009) - This writer has been solving cryptics for 40 years and can usually crack Araucaria, though it might take a couple of days.

moredefinition.definition: To hang loosely with the ability to swing.
examples: 2013, David Simpson, "The Guardian Weekly" — Like most human activities, ballooning has sponsored heroes and hucksters and a good deal in between. For every dedicated scientist patiently recording atmospheric pressure and wind speed while shivering at high altitudes, there is a carnival barker with a bevy of pretty girls willing to dangle from a basket or parachute down to earth.
His feet would dangle in the water.

moredefinition.definition: To hang or trail something loosely.
examples: I like to sit on the edge and dangle my feet in the water.

moredefinition.definition: (slang, ice hockey, lacrosse) The action of performing a move or deke with the puck in order to get past a defender or goalie; perhaps because of the resemblance to dangling the puck on a string.
examples: He dangled around three players and the goalie to score.

moredefinition.definition: (medicine) Of a patient: to be positioned with the legs hanging over the edge of the bed.
examples: 1976, R. Winifred Heyward Johnson, ‎Douglass W. Johnson, Introduction to Nursing Care (page 139) - Record the time and duration of dangling, patient's pulse and respirations and patient's general tolerance of the procedure. [...] The next step usually in getting the patient out of bed is sitting [...]

2012, Judith M. Wilkinson, ‎Leslie S. Treas, Pocket Nursing Skills: What You Need to Know Now - [P]ivot to bring the patient's legs over the side of the bed. Be Smart! Stay with the patient as he dangles.

moredefinition.definition: (medicine) To position (a patient) in this way.
examples: 2012, Judith M. Wilkinson, ‎Leslie S. Treas, Pocket Nursing Skills: What You Need to Know Now - Using proper body mechanics for dangling a patient at the side of the bed.

moredefinition.definition: (dated) To trail or follow around.
An agent of one intelligence agency or group who pretends to be interested in defecting or turning to another intelligence agency or group.
(slang, ice hockey, lacrosse) The action of dangling; a series of complex stick tricks and fakes in order to defeat the defender in style.
examples: That was a sick dangle for a great goal!

moredefinition.definition: A dangling ornament or decoration.
examples: 1941, Flora Thompson, "Over to Candleford" — So her father wrote to Mrs. Herring, and one day she arrived and turned out to be a little, lean old lady with a dark brown mole on one leathery cheek and wearing a black bonnet decorated with jet dangles, like tiny fishing rods.

moredefinition.definition: Suspended from above.
The act of hanging something so that it can move freely; suspension.
The act of following or trailing around.
(colloquial, US) All out, open throttle, with all you have.
To delay or postpone; especially to postpone induction into military service.

(American football) After winning the opening coin toss, to postpone until the start of the second half a team's choice of whether to kick off or receive (and to allow the opposing team to make this choice at the start of the first half).
To delay, to wait.
(law) To submit to the opinion or desire of another in respect to their judgment or authority.
To render, to offer.
To refuse to allow
examples: The prisoners were disallowed to contact with a lawyer.

moredefinition.definition: To reject as invalid, untrue, or improper
examples: The goal was disallowed because the player was offside.

2012, Phil McNulty, "BBC Sport" — England will regard it as a measure of justice for Frank Lampard's disallowed goal against Germany in Bloemfontein at the 2010 World Cup - but it was also an illustration of how they rode their luck for long periods in front of a predictably partisan home crowd.

moredefinition.definition: To grant, give, admit, accord, afford, or yield; to let one have.
examples: to allow a servant his liberty; to allow a free passage; to allow one day for rest

2004, Constance, transl. Garnett, "The Darling: and Other Stories" — [...] he needed a great deal of money, but his uncle only allowed him two thousand roubles a year, which was not enough, and for days together he would run about Moscow with his tongue out, as the saying is.

moredefinition.definition: To acknowledge; to accept as true; to concede; to accede to an opinion.
examples: to allow a right; to allow a claim; to allow the truth of a proposition

moredefinition.definition: To grant (something) as a deduction or an addition; especially to abate or deduct.
examples: To allow a sum for leakage.

moredefinition.definition: To grant license to; to permit; to consent to.
examples: To allow a son to be absent.
Smoking allowed only in designated areas.

moredefinition.definition: To not bar or obstruct.
examples: Although I don't consent to their holding such meetings, I will allow them for the time being.

2013, Leo Hickman, "The Guardian Weekly" — The use of algorithms in policing is one example of their increasing influence on our lives. And, as their ubiquity spreads, so too does the debate around whether we should allow ourselves to become so reliant on them – and who, if anyone, is policing their use.

moredefinition.definition: To acknowledge or concede.

moredefinition.definition: The rejection of, or opposition to, religious beliefs, (inherent or objective) moral principles, legal rules, etc., often due to the view that life is meaningless (sense 1).
examples: 2010, Christopher L. Fisher, "Human Significance in Theology and the Natural Sciences: An Ecumenical Perspective with Reference to Pannenberg, Rahner, and Zizioulas" — [Robert] Jenson observes that treating "other animals like humans is also to treat humans like other animals … Anthropological nihilism [seems] relatively harmless in … the 'animal rights' movement, but has been tested in frightful adult practice," e.g., Nazi socialism, or modern anthropological nihilisms evident in abortion on demand, euthanasia, and infanticide.

moredefinition.definition: The view that all endeavours are devoid of objective meaning.
examples: 1983, Dave Marsh, "The New Rolling Stone Record Guide: [...]" — [T]he band members sweat hard enough to earn their pretensions, and maybe even their nihilism.

2004, Cornel West, "Democracy Matters: Winning the Fight against Imperialism" — [W]hat is most terrifying—including the perennial threat of cowardly terrorists—is the insidious growth of deadening nihilisms across political lines, nihilisms that have been suffocating the deep democratic energies in America. In Race Matters, I examined the increasing nihilism in black America as the "lived experience of coping with a life of horrifying meaninglessness, hopelessness, and (most important) lovelessness."

moredefinition.definition: (politics) The rejection of non-proven or non-rationalized assertions in the social and political spheres of society.
examples: 1988, William Dean, "History Making History: The New Historicism in American Religious Thought" — As with the original American historicists, they accept only historical references and deny all extrahistorical references, including those implicit in idealism and positivism. [...] They deny both authoritarian and subjectivistic nihilisms, and they affirm the responsibility of the subject.

moredefinition.definition: (psychiatry) A delusion that oneself or the world, or parts thereof, have ceased to exist.
examples: 2009, Tim Bayne, "The Oxford Companion to Consciousness" — Individuals with schizophrenia often cycle between nihilistic and solipsistic moods—when in the grip of nihilism they appear to have lost experiential contact with their very existence, [...]

2009, Arjan W. Braam, "Religion and Spirituality in Psychiatry" — Melancholia is the most typical and classical presentation of depression with several compelling features such as impoverishment of emotional life and delusions of nihilism or guilt.

moredefinition.definition: (Russia, politics, historical) Alternative letter-case form of Nihilism ("a Russian movement of the 1860s that rejected all authority and promoted the use of violence for political change")
Something that is regarded as meaningless.
examples: 2003, Lorraine Adams, "The Washington Post" — She [Susan Sontag] has honored beauty and justness, and she has chronicled how they were almost extinguished in the most devastatingly genocidal century to date. Without her, the dead Iraqi child on al-Jazeera would be just one of many, a signpost pointing toward the twin nihilisms of inevitability and ignorance.

moredefinition.definition: Any smell, whether fragrant or offensive.
(figuratively) A strong, pervasive quality.
(figuratively) Esteem.
(now rare) Something which produces a scent; incense, a perfume.
Alternative form of odor
Without planning or thinking ahead.
examples: She gave an offhand speech.

moredefinition.definition: Careless; without sufficient thought or consideration.
examples: He doesn't realise how hurtful his offhand remarks can be.

moredefinition.definition: Curt, abrupt, unfriendly.
examples: She was quite offhand with me yesterday.

moredefinition.definition: Right away, immediately, without thinking about it.
examples: Offhand, I'd guess that that's a yellow-bellied sapsucker.

moredefinition.definition: In an offhand manner.

moredefinition.definition: Allowing little light to pass through, not translucent or transparent.

(figuratively) Obtuse, stupid.
(computing) Describes a type for which higher-level callers have no knowledge of data values or their representations; all operations are carried out by the type's defined abstract operators.

moredefinition.definition: (of ideas or attitudes) Inflexible, old-fashioned.

examples: 2018, Newton Taylor, "Acadia" — At Wanda's house, two nights before the wedding, she, Jenny, and two other girls were doing shots with beer chasers while Tom and I and another guy watched as they all got ossified.

moredefinition.definition: To transform (or cause to transform) from a softer animal substance into bone; particularly the processes of growth in humans and animals.
(animate) To become (or cause to become) inflexible and rigid in habits or opinions.
examples: 1996, Peter Schwartz, The Art of the Long View, page 96 - Before long, the entire organization ossifies.
2006, Michael S. Jones, Metaphysics of Religion: Lucian Blaga and Contemporary Philosophy, page 79 - Possession of absolute knowledge would ossify the human spirit, quenching human creativity;

moredefinition.definition: (inanimate) To grow (or cause to grow) formulaic and permanent.

2005, Michelle Goldberg, "The war on 'Munich'", Salon.com, December 20, 2005 - [T]he charge threatens to ossify into conventional wisdom before the movie's audience can get to theaters to see how misguided it is.

moredefinition.definition: (rare) To calcify.

She only dresses like that because she thinks she is getting the boys' attention; she doesn’t even like the clothes. She’s such a poseur.

2013, Peter Wilby, "The Guardian Weekly" — Imagine a country where children do nothing but play until they start compulsory schooling at age seven. Then, without exception, they attend comprehensives until the age of 16. Charging school fees is illegal, and so is sorting pupils into ability groups by streaming or setting.

moredefinition.definition: to impute or ascribe
examples: 1966, Stringfellow Barr, "The Mask of Jove" — He lacked the art of wounding with the sword, and in any case his critics charged that he shrank from steel; but his invective was worthy of Demosthenes and his words drew blood.

moredefinition.definition: to call to account; to challenge
to place a burden or load on or in
examples: 1911, The Encyclopedia Britannica, entry on Moya: [A] huge torrent of boiling black mud, charged with blocks of rock and moving with enormous rapidity, rolled like an avalanche down the gorge.

subdefinitions.definition: to ornament with or cause to bear
examples: to charge an architectural member with a moulding
He charges three roses.

subdefinitions.definition: (heraldry) to add to or represent on
examples: He charges his shield with three roses or.

moredefinition.definition: to move forward quickly and forcefully, particularly in combat and/or on horseback

subdefinitions.definition: (military) to attack by moving forward quickly in a group
examples: The impetuous corps charged the enemy lines.

subdefinitions.definition: (cricket, of a batsman) to take a few steps down the pitch towards the bowler as he delivers the ball, either to disrupt the length of the delivery, or to get into a better position to hit the ball

moredefinition.definition: (of a hunting dog) to lie on the belly and be still (A command given by a hunter to a dog)
(possibly archaic) to sell at a given price.
examples: to charge coal at $5 per unit

moredefinition.definition: A young toad or frog in its larval stage of development that lives in water, has a tail and no legs, and, like a fish, breathes through gills.
(by extension) The aquatic larva of any amphibian.
examples: salamander tadpole

moredefinition.definition: A type of cargo bike that has two wheels in front and one in back.
(psychology) A child's basic drawing of a human being, having a detailed head but only sticks for the body and limbs.
Lacking in courage or confidence.
examples: 1963, Margery Allingham, "The China Governess" — When Timothy and Julia hurried up the staircase to the bedroom floor, where a considerable commotion was taking place, Tim took Barry Leach with him. [...]. The captive made no resistance and came not only quietly but in a series of eager little rushes like a timid dog on a choke chain.
John's a very timid person. I'll doubt he'll be brave enough to face his brother.

moredefinition.definition: A state of great disorder or uncertainty.
examples: 2012, Phil McNulty, "BBC Sport" — Oleg Blokhin's side lost the talismanic Andriy Shevchenko to the substitutes' bench because of a knee injury but still showed enough to put England through real turmoil in spells.

moredefinition.definition: Harassing labour; trouble; disturbance.
examples: 1918, W. B. Maxwell, "The Mirror and the Lamp" — The turmoil went on-no rest, no peace. […] It was nearly eleven o'clock now, and he strolled out again. In the little fair created by the costers' barrows the evening only seemed beginning; and the naphtha flares made one's eyes ache, the men's voices grated harshly, and the girls' faces saddened one.

moredefinition.definition: (obsolete) To be disquieted or confused; to be in commotion.
(obsolete) To harass with commotion; to disquiet; to worry.
Physically strong and active.
Mentally strong and active.
Rapid of growth.
examples: a vigorous shrub

moredefinition.definition: (American spelling) Alternative form of vigour
Active strength or force of body or mind; capacity for exertion, physically, intellectually, or morally; energy.
(biology) Strength or force in animal or vegetable nature or action.
examples: A plant grows with vigour.

moredefinition.definition: Strength; efficacy; potency.
A twisted strand of fiber used for knitting or weaving.
(nautical) Bundles of fibers twisted together, and which in turn are twisted in bundles to form strands, which in their turn are twisted or plaited to form rope.
A story, a tale, especially one that is incredible.
examples: 1913, Joseph C. Lincoln, "Mr. Pratt's Patients" — I told him about everything I could think of; and what I couldn't think of he did. He asked about six questions during my yarn, but every question had a point to it. At the end he bowed and thanked me once more. As a thanker he was main-truck high; I never see anybody so polite.
1930, Norman Lindsay, "Redheap" — "I'm hanged if I know how you've got the immortal rind to come at me with a yarn like this."

moredefinition.definition: To tell a story or stories.
examples: 1935, Christopher Isherwood, Mr Norris Changes Trains (U.S. title: The Last of Mr Norris), Chapter Thirteen, in The Berlin Stories, New York: New Directions, 1963, p. 152,[https://archive.org/details/berlinstories00ishe] - “Well, well!” exclaimed Mr. van Hoorn. “Here are the boys! As hungry as hunters, I’ll be bound! And we two old fogies have been wasting the whole afternoon yarning away indoors. My goodness, is it as late as that? I say, I want my tea!”

1942, Neville Shute, Pied Piper, New York: William Morrow & Co., Chapter 7,[http://fadedpage.com/books/20140425/html.php] - They had stayed in some little pension and had gone for little, bored walks while the colonel went out in the boats with the fisherman, or sat yarning with them in the café.
